Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Bio-Inspired Approach to Engineer Zeolite Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

#1151098
P.I.: Jeffrey Rimer

Tailoring crystallization of zeolites with predictable structural outcomes is a challenge in zeolite catalyst design, wherein few synthetic approaches are amenable to systematic and precise manipulation of material properties. Developing facile, inexpensive routes to precisely control crystal habit (i.e. morphology and orientation) can address design limitations that often marginalize catalyst performance and can hinder their commercial viability. Prof. Jeffrey Rimer of the University of Houston proposes in his CAREER award study to develop a rational design strategy for improving the mass transport properties of zeolite catalysts, notably a reduction in the internal pore diffusion path length and an increase in the exterior pore surface area, which are known to markedly improve activity and stability. With this award, Rimer will leverage research thrusts in crystal engineering and surface science to tailor zeolite crystallization at an interfacial level, using a bio-inspired approach to tune crystal habit and surface architecture, and ultimately to test catalyst activity as a function of these variables. This design approach mimics crystallization in nature by using modifiers with molecular recognition for binding to specific surfaces and mediating step growth on crystal faces. Initiatives will focus on reactions of model compounds with a long-term trajectory of establishing a comprehensive platform to design, model, and test zeolites for alternative energy applications.

This award will be used to strengthen outreach initiatives at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate levels to promote engineering education and research. Rimer has partnered with KIPP Houston High School (a minority institution ranked 16th in national college readiness) to establish a dynamic program for student and teacher (NSF-RET) research at the University of Houston, guest lectures on engineering topics to KIPP AP Chemistry students, lesson plans that integrate results of Rimer's research, and an annual seminar to promote increased interest in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on three objectives related to the rational design of zeolites with the goal of controlling and optimizing their properties for catalytic applications. The specific aims of the project included the use of crystal growth modifiers as a bio-inspired approach to tailor zeolite size and morphology, the pioneering use of atomic force microscopy (AFM) for solvothermal in situ imaging of zeolite crystallization in real time, and the elucidation of crystal growth mechanisms governed by complex nonclassical pathways.

Intellectual Merit: Key outcomes of this CAREER Award include the validation of a versatile and economical method to tailor the physicochemical properties of zeolite catalysts through the use of growth modifiers. This method was applied to three commercial zeolites and we were able to demonstrate the ability to selectively tune crystal size over three orders of magnitude. Research thrusts in zeolite synthesis also led to a new platform for organic-free zeolite synthesis as a commercially useful method to control zeolite composition and polymorphism. Notable outcomes included the synthesis of high-silica LTA (HOU-2) and FAU (HOU-3) with Si/Al ratios that exceed those of their commercial analogues. The development of kinetic phase diagrams we influential in the identification of unique polymorphs, such as those for zeolite GIS (polymorphs P1 and P2), where subtle differences in structure were shown to result in dramatic improvement in hydrothermal stability. These studies also spurred a systematic investigation of zeolite nucleation that led to the identification of nonclassical mechanisms for amorphous precursor assembly and evolution. The most significant outcome of this award, however, was the development of solvothermal AFM to monitor the growth of zeolite surfaces in real time. This technique has revealed new findings of zeolite crystallization mechanisms, and the relative roles of classical and nonclassical routes. Collectively, this project resulted in 16 publications (including 6 cover articles) and 4 patent applications.

Broader Impacts: The optimization of zeolite catalysts can have a significant influence on their performance in industrial applications, many of which have socioeconomic importance (e.g., energy and the environment). The ability to tailor the physicochemical properties of zeolites through versatile, facile, and cheap methods has true commercial appeal. Moreover, the discovery of zeolite growth mechanisms is providing evidence of non-classical pathways that is a general field of research with resurgent interest due to the growing number of examples of crystals that grow by way of particle attachment (as opposed to classical layer growth via molecule addition). Indeed, fundamental knowledge gained from these studies may have broader utility for describing phenomena outside of zeolite synthesis. This award has led to the design of commercially-viable methods to engineering zeolite catalysts. In addition, this project has made a significant impact on student education by sponsoring the research of five graduate students and four undergraduate students, including one female and one disabled student. Findings from this project have been disseminated by the PI and students at numerous national conferences. Moreover, the PI has worked with the MIT-Lemelson organization to coordinate high school student tours of the Cullen College of Engineering at the University of Houston and to promote STEM education. Throughout the course of this project, high school students and teachers have also spent summers working with graduate students to learn cutting-edge techniques in zeolite synthesis and characterization.
